intro: Passiflora tarapotina, commonly known as the Andean passionflower, is a species native to the Andean regions of South America. It is a climbing vine characterized by its heart-shaped leaves and showy, colorful flowers that resemble a crown. The plant produces edible berries that are often used in local cuisines. It thrives in humid, tropical climates and is often found in forest understories. Its botanical features make it an important species for both ecological and ornamental purposes.
